title: Sans Serif Font
content:
Does anyone recognize this font?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [IMG\_1598.PNG](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415000500/http:/typophile.com/files/IMG_1598.PNG) | 60.69 KB |
author: pacedesign

comments.content:
Great suggestion (as usual) by Kevin with Sisco, probably the best ready-to-go option. But I don't think it's the one. Mainly because of /R (over-)extended leg and even if it means customization, I'd rather think it's [Klavika](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415000500/http:/processtypefoundry.com/fonts/klavika). Some details are off (but easily customized) like crossbar-less /G and /Y fork position. Klavika is actually used all over their identity from graphics to print materials and packaging. They also use [Titilium](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415000500/http:/www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/Titillium) for their [online identity](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415000500/http:/www.thegrayl.com/), also similar to Klavika.  
A better look to their logo (from this [PDF](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415000500/http:/static1.squarespace.com/static/52a101f6e4b0ddb9096493f1/t/545ad15fe4b042d9849e64be/1415237983158/20141103_GRAYL_CUP_MANUAL_v1r6.pdf))

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415000500im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Untitled-1_5125.png)
